default.prompt: How does React Native handle high-density images (Retina/Super Retina)?
options: It automatically resizes one single image to fit all screens
By naming files with @2x and @3x suffixes, RN automatically picks the correct one
You must manually check screen density and import different files
React Native only supports SVG for high-density screens
default.explanation: If you have 'icon.png', 'icon@2x.png', and 'icon@3x.png', the packager will bundle them and the app will pick the right one based on the device's pixel density.
default.interviewTip: This ensures your images look sharp on an iPhone 15 Pro without wasting memory on an older Android device.

default.prompt: What is the mandatory prop for an <Image> component when loading a remote URL?
options: src
url
source={{ uri: '...' }}
source={require('...')}
default.explanation: Remote images require an object with a 'uri' key. Local images use the 'require' syntax.
default.interviewTip: Remember that for remote images, you MUST specify width and height in the style, or they will default to 0x0.

options: It determines the file format of the image
It defines how the image should be fitted within its container (cover, contain, stretch, etc.)
It compresses the image for better performance
It is used to rotate the image
default.explanation: resizeMode is the React Native equivalent of CSS 'object-fit'. 'cover' is the default.
default.interviewTip: Use 'contain' when you need the whole image to be visible without cropping.

default.prompt: What is 'FastImage' and why is it popular in the community?
options: A component that makes images download faster over the internet
A 3rd-party library that provides aggressive caching and better performance than the core Image component
The new name for the standard Image component
A tool for editing images inside the app
default.explanation: react-native-fast-image (or Expo Image) handles complex caching, flickers, and priority loading much better than the standard library.
default.interviewTip: For apps with heavy image feeds (like Instagram clones), FastImage is practically a requirement.

default.prompt: How do you render SVG files in React Native?
options: Using the standard <Image> component
Using the <Svg> tag from the core library
Using the 'react-native-svg' library
SVGs are not supported in React Native
default.explanation: React Native does not support SVG out of the box. You must use 'react-native-svg' and often 'react-native-svg-transformer' to use them as components.
default.interviewTip: SVGs are ideal for icons as they are resolution-independent and have a very small file size.

default.prompt: What does the 'capInsets' prop (iOS only) do for an Image?
options: Sets the padding of the image
Defines a '9-patch' style resizing where corners remain un-stretched
Limits the image memory usage
Adds a rounded corner to the image
default.explanation: capInsets allows you to create resizable images (like speech bubbles) where only the middle part stretches, preserving the corner shapes.
default.interviewTip: On Android, this is usually handled by using a '.9.png' (nine-patch) file.

default.prompt: Which component is used for playing videos in React Native?
options: <VideoPlayer>
<Video> from 'react-native-video' or 'expo-av'
<Media>
<Movie>
default.explanation: There is no built-in Video component. 'react-native-video' (CLI) or 'expo-av' (Expo) are the industry standards.
default.interviewTip: Video playback usually happens on a separate native thread to prevent UI freezing.

default.prompt: What is 'Image Caching' in the context of mobile apps?
options: Deleting old images to save space
Storing downloaded images on the device so they don't need to be re-downloaded
A way to encrypt images
Converting PNGs to JPEGs
default.explanation: Caching improves UX by showing images instantly on subsequent app opens and reduces data usage.
default.interviewTip: Standard RN Image has basic caching, but libraries like FastImage offer fine-grained control (e.g., Cache-Control headers).

default.prompt: How do you specify a placeholder image to show while a remote image is loading?
options: Use the 'placeholder' prop
Use the 'defaultSource' prop (iOS only) or a state-based conditional
React Native does this automatically
It's not possible without a 3rd party library
default.explanation: defaultSource is the native way on iOS. For cross-platform, you usually manage an 'isLoading' state and show a local image until the remote one is ready.
default.interviewTip: Modern libraries like 'expo-image' support blur-hash placeholders, which look very professional.

default.prompt: What is the benefit of using 'base64' encoded images?
options: They are smaller in size
They can be embedded directly in the JS code/JSON without a separate network request
They are higher quality
They are easier to style
default.explanation: Base64 is useful for tiny icons or small dynamic previews, but it increases the JS bundle size and is slower to decode for large images.
default.interviewTip: Avoid base64 for large photos; itâ€™s about 33% larger than the binary file.

default.prompt: How can you pre-load an image before it is displayed?
options: It's not possible
Use Image.prefetch('url')
Put the image in a hidden View
Use the useEffect hook
default.explanation: Image.prefetch allows you to download an image to the disk cache ahead of time.
default.interviewTip: Pre-fetching is great for the 'next' image in a slideshow or gallery.

default.prompt: What is 'blurRadius' in an Image component?
options: A prop to make the corners rounded
A prop to add a Gaussian blur to the image
A way to reduce image quality
A prop for image transparency
default.explanation: blurRadius takes a number; the higher the number, the more blurred the image appears.
default.interviewTip: This is often used for background effects or 'NSFW' content filtering.

default.prompt: How do you load an image from the user's photo gallery?
options: Using <Image source='gallery://...' />
Using a library like 'expo-image-picker' or 'react-native-image-crop-picker'
React Native has a built-in <Gallery> component
Ask the user to copy-paste the image
default.explanation: Accessing the gallery requires native permissions and a picker interface provided by these libraries.
default.interviewTip: Always check for 'Permissions' before attempting to open the gallery.

default.prompt: What does 'onLoad' prop in an Image do?
options: Triggers when the image starts downloading
Triggers once the image has successfully loaded
Loads the image into memory
Refreshes the image
default.explanation: onLoad is called when the image finish loading successfully. Use 'onError' for failures.
default.interviewTip: You can use this to trigger a fade-in animation once the image is ready.

default.prompt: What is the impact of rendering many large high-resolution images in a FlatList?
options: None, React Native handles it
High memory consumption and potential 'Out of Memory' (OOM) crashes
The app will become faster
The battery will charge faster
default.explanation: Images are the biggest memory hogs. Un-optimized lists of images will quickly crash a mobile app.
default.interviewTip: This is why list virtualization and image caching libraries are essential.

options: An image with 9 different colors
A resizable bitmap that defines which areas can be stretched
A collage of 9 photos
An image for 9-inch tablets
default.explanation: Mainly used in Android, it allows images (like buttons with shadows) to scale without distorting the borders.
default.interviewTip: React Native supports these natively on Android using the .9.png extension.

default.prompt: How do you handle different images for Dark Mode?
options: Use the 'appearance' prop in Image
Use the 'useColorScheme' hook to switch the 'source' prop based on the theme
React Native does this automatically if you add a '_dark' suffix
Images cannot be changed for dark mode
default.explanation: You manually detect the theme and provide a different 'require' or 'uri' to the Image component.
default.interviewTip: For logos or icons, it's often better to use SVGs and change their 'fill' color instead of swapping files.
